sn3.15:4.1: Then King Ajātasattu Vedehiputta of Magadha mobilized an army of four divisions and marched to Kāsi to attack King Pasenadi of Kosala.
sn3.15:4.2: When King Pasenadi heard of this,
sn3.15:4.4: he mobilized an army of four divisions and marched to Kāsi to defend it against Ajātasattu.
sn3.15:4.5: Then the two kings met in battle.
sn3.15:4.6: And in that battle Pasenadi defeated Ajātasattu and captured him alive.
sn3.15:4.8: “Even though I’ve never betrayed this King Ajātasattu, he betrayed me. Still, he is my nephew.
sn3.15:4.9: Now that I’ve vanquished all of Ajātasattu’s elephant troops, cavalry, chariots, and infantry, why don’t I let him go with just his life?”
sn3.15:6.4: told the Buddha what had happened.
sn3.15:9.1: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha recited these verses:
sn3.15:10.2: as long as it serves his ends.
sn3.15:10.3: But as soon as others plunder him,
sn3.15:11.1: For the fool thinks they’ve got away with it
sn3.15:11.2: as long as the wickedness doesn’t ripen.
sn3.15:12.4: and a bully creates a bully.
